name: BBC Master AIV
language: BBC BASIC. BCPL provided with package.
keyboard: Standard QWERTY, 10 function keys + arrows, plus numeric keypad
vram: Taken from main RAM, up to 44K?
text: 80 x 32/25 (2 colors) / 40 x 32/25 (2 or 4 colors) / 20 x 32 (16 colors) / 40 x 25 (Teletext display)
graphics: 640 x 256 (2 colors) / 320 x 256 (4 colors) / 160 x 256 (16 colors)
colors: 16 (8 colors + flashing option), True colour from the video data on LV-ROM
ports: 1MHz BUS, Analogue, RGB, Disk, RS423, User port, Econet, Tape, Parallel printer. Captive SCSI lead.
description:
In 1986, the 900th Anniversary of the Norman Domesday Book, the BBC and 
the National Curriculum, amongst other UK bodies, endeavoured to 
produced a 20th Century equivalent. Recently the Domesday project has 
had renewed interest, as the sense of producing such an ambitious 
undertaking then storing the results on a strange, and now forgotten, 
format has been called into question many times since!

For old-computers.com readers, the interesting bits are not terribly 
interesting - but they are scarce. The presentation was viewable on one 
of two platforms - the main, and the one most associated with it, was 
the BBC Master AIV (Advanced Interactive Video). This isn't an 
'official' term - as far as Acorn and the BBC were concerned, they 
wanted schools to purchase the system in the belief that it was 
essentially what they were used to. The BBC Master was an off the shelf 
Master Turbo, with an additional SCSI interface (possibly 
electronically derived from the SCSI interface built into the ACW), and 
an additional filing system to access the LV-ROM.

The VP415 LV-ROM was an industrial Philips Laservision player, already 
'programmable' according to the Laservision standards. The storage was 
broken down into volumes, with data encoded along with the video 
content (which can be played separately). The SCSI interface allowed 
data retrieval but this was also possible via the RS-232 interface - 
and a module to allow the other machine popular in schools at the time 
access - the RM Nimbus. The actual data format on the disc was 
controlled by LV-DOS in the player, and VFS in the BBC series computer. 
Whilst the Master AIV was most definitely marketed for this 
application, the documentation is quite vague about whether a BBC B 
could be used, implying that merely the VFS ROM is required!

Video from the laserdisc was mixed using a genlock incorporated in the 
base of the VP415 with data generated by the Domesday applications and 
displayed on a SCART monitor.

Applications allowed searching of film content, further exploration of 
the information, such as going into a house pictured (within 
limitations, of course!), and statistical analysis of data gathered in 
a project that involved schools all over the UK. It's quite likely that 
many people of my generation contributed, in some small part, to the 
Domesday project.

Additional discs were produced for educational purposes, hoping to 
expand the applications of the AIV system, but the late 80s was to see 
the advent of Microsoft's "Multimedia PC" standard, Philips' own CDi, 
and many other CD (rather than LD) based systems. LV-ROM, in addition 
to the video and still frames, could store just under 400Mb of data on 
a 12" optical disc - whilst the video would take up more space on CD, 
the media was physically fragile and was eventually to be rendered 
obsolete with the end of the VP415.

Projects to restore the Domesday project are hampered by copyright law 
and the restrictions of accessing the data, The most successful is 
Leeds University's CAMeLION project, an emulated system, with some 
PC-based applications. I am undertaking my own 'accessible' project, to 
attempt to make the material useable in a wide range of consumer 
friendly appliances, but like everyone else, am tied by the fragility 
of the hardware (if anyone has parts for the VP415 I need spares!) and 
of course, copyright law.

___________

Thanks A LOT to Richard Kilpatrick for all this info.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD SYSTEMS</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The amazing TI-99/4A.<br> A computer for 1800fr"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert for Instructor 50, Byte March 1979, Page 45.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Adam Trinfo for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1983 BADGES</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACE 1000 ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Your personnal computer for 670 F"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert for correspondance courses using MPF-1 computers.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MEMORY BOARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>Vector Graphics also sold various cards for any S-100 systems. This one is a 8 Kb. static RAM card solded for $265 in kit version and $350 assembled.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">No one knows better than Microsoft how to increase your TRS-80 BASIC's power. Microsoft created the TRS-80 Level ll and Disk BASIC plus the industry standard Microsoft BASIC...<br><br> ...Microsoft Level lll BASIC is an enhancement to the Level ll. It contains all Disk BASIC features not already in Level ll and it adds six new Level lll exclusives...<br> ...Advanced graphics is Level lll's most exciting addition to the TRS-80 - and it's exclusive. Draw a line, outline or solid box by specifying just two points, then save it and put it back with BASIC statement. You'll find yourself writing more programs with charts, graphs and even animation...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future....  </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Thomson, you make me micro"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT. #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>I love this advert ! Their pullovers are so... colored.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.1000bit.net" target="_blank">www.1000bit.net</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably one of the first adverts for the Osborne 1.<br> Personal Computing, February 1982.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Stop in a store near you. Take a look. You'll be instantly taken with some of the features that make the IBM Personal Computer so different...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMMERCIAL PAMPHLET - PAGE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">thanks to Richard Rogers </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>This ad uses actors, except for IMSAI's Finance Director Hersch Mandelman as the "Milk Man".</blockquote>

emulator.name: The BBC Lives !
emulator.description: This excellent site has a complete list of Acorn systems emulators

builtInGames: BBC BASIC. BCPL provided with package.
peripherals: Philips VP415 LV-ROM, Acorn AKF-11 monitor (SCART), Acorn Trackerball (Marconi RB2).
